Garbage collection is a ritual that is similar in many developed countries. In most places, it is free to dispose of rubbish. However, if rubbish disposal is free, people will produce too much rubbish. To reduce the amount of rubbish that is produced, people need to be charged for disposing of their waste. This will give them an incentive to throw out less and recycle more.
When a town starts charging for rubbish disposal, the number of bags or cans that are collected usually decreases. However, this is often due to the 'Seattle stomp', which is when people cram more garbage into each container. This can be done better by machines at landfill sites than by individuals.
In addition to the reduction in the number of bags or cans that are collected, there is also an increase in the weight of materials recycled. This is because people are more likely to recycle if they have to pay to dispose of their rubbish.

To be successful in your career, you need to be able to communicate effectively, be creative, and be able to work well with others. If you are not able to do these things, you will not be able to enjoy your work, even if you have a high salary or a lot of status.
There are a number of things that can make work more fulfilling. One is to find a job that you are passionate about. Another is to be able to have a conversation with your boss and colleagues. If you are able to do these things, you will be more likely to be successful in your career.

Broadcasting is a technology that was originally used to sow seeds broadly. It is also a metaphor for optimistic modernism. It is about planned growth and the production of a rich harvest.
Television is related to other two-way forms of communication. It was envisaged as a centralised 'mass' medium. However, transmission to private homes from some centralised unit was simply in keeping with both socio-economic structures and the dominant ways of life in modern societies.
In the early 1930s, there were two little-known, distinct alternatives to the way television was organised. One was experiments with two-way television as a possible replacement for the ordinary telephone. The other was various popular science journals that had detailed articles about how to construct television transmitters and receivers.
But Big Business saw the possibilities for mass sales of domestic sets and centralised broadcasting to a dispersed domestic audience was clearly the most adequate organisation of the medium. As working-class people achieved improved standards of living and entered 'consumer' society, the dreams of the home as a fully equipped centre for entertainment and diverse cultural experiences became realisable for the majority of inhabitants of Western nation-states.

However, audiences and performers meet on more equal terms in the theatre than elsewhere. Music and theatre can both be very enjoyable art forms. They can bring people together and make them feel happy.

In those days, the council houses in West Earlham were like row after row of huddled, dingy dwellings. The chemicals from the factory came and hung around the doors and gardens with a strong smell of sulphur. The most common sight in that part of Norwich early in the morning was a paperboy wrinkling his nose in disgust as he walked on someone's front path. Most of my early life I've forgotten, but I have a memory of sitting on a vantage point near an upstairs window and looking at the houses as they faded away into the distance. Later on there are other memories, like faces that I can't put names to, my mother ironing towels in the back room of a house that I don't think was ours, and snow falling over the turrets of the great mansion at Earlham. My mother was a small, precise and nearly always angry woman. She was quite the most solitary person I have ever known, as alone in a room full of people as on a moor. To particularise, it meant not straying into neighbours' gardens or jeopardising their rose bushes as you walked down the street; it meant sitting for long half-hours in a silent dining room, with your hands folded across your chest, listening to radio programmes that your mother liked. It was as if a giant paperweight, composed of the West Earlham houses, my mother and her cronies, the obligation to 'behave proper', lay across my shoulders, and that it was my duty immediately to grow up and start the work of prising it free.

The houses on my street are different. Each one is unique. They are like the little troughs in the cement that lead water away from the roof gutters. They are all different shapes and sizes.
As I walk down the street, I see the changes that have happened over the years. The porches are lower and the front yards are smaller. The houses have changed a lot. They have been turned into stores. But some of the stores have also been turned back into homes.
I also see the changes in the people who live on my street. They have become older and their children have grown up. But they are still friendly.

Charles Darwin thought that humans have a natural tendency to cry. It is not clear why we cry, but there are a few possible reasons. One reason is that crying can help us to connect with others. It can also be used to express sympathy or sadness. Sometimes, we cry involuntarily when we hear inspiring music or moving speeches. We may also cry when watching a sentimental film. However, the most important reason for crying is its social function. Tears can help us to build trust and social connectedness.

The Earth is getting warmer, and this is causing a lot of changes to the planet. The changes are affecting plants, animals, water, and soils. Humans have learned to use natural resources to our advantage, but any changes to these resources have to be taken seriously.
One of the biggest problems is that we do not understand fully all the processes of the climatic system. Despite this, most people agree that the rate of change will be faster than anything we have previously experienced.
The effects of climate change are already being felt around the world. For example, the average annual global surface temperature has increased by between 1C and 3.5C since 1900. The average sea level around the world has also risen by 15-95 cm. And changes in the spatial and temporal patterns of precipitation are occurring.
Climate change is also having a negative impact on glaciers. Glaciers are melting at an alarming rate, which is causing a number of problems, including changes in vegetation, wildlife habitats, and sea levels.
The rise in sea levels is one of the most dramatic and visible effects of global warming. It is causing a lot of problems for people living in coastal zones, including increased flooding and inundation.

There is a lot of work to do before then, but the efforts to achieve these ambitious goals will not be in vain.

Art is a powerful form of expression that can bring joy and understanding to people. However, sometimes the complexity of art can make it difficult for people to enjoy and understand. When art is separated from its connection to human experience, it becomes isolated and difficult to relate to. To understand art, we need to forget it for a time and turn aside from it. Instead, we need to focus on the ordinary forces and conditions of experience that we do not usually regard as aesthetic. This means arriving at the theory of art by means of a detour. Once we have done this, we can appreciate art in its raw, unrefined form.

If you work for an advertising agency, the early years of the 1990s were probably the toughest of your professional life. There was a recession in business that was bad enough. It was longer, deeper and more severe than anyone could have predicted. In Britain, it meant that a lot of people lost their jobs and homes. Every single business in the country was affected. Advertising people are often under pressure because they are seen as the ones who are spearheading efforts to support the bottom line. They also have to deal with the problem of increasingly being asked to do their ever more difficult jobs with smaller and smaller budgets.
However, there has also been a rise in the perceived importance of the marketing process. The notion that companies should be making sure they are producing services and goods that their customers want, as opposed to merely what it is convenient for them to provide, is not new. And, it's not unfair to say that many companies have only recently begun to put this idea into practice. The consequences have been that marketing activities have at last begun to be given the attention they deserve by management, and that a few brands have actually begun to be genuinely marketed.

When I was at university, I decided I wanted to be a chef. It was an unusual choice, but I was unhappy at university and I thought being a chef would be the perfect antidote to my problems. I started to learn how to cook by reading cookbooks, roaming markets and delicatessens and preparing extravagant meals.
One day, I was eating at a famous restaurant in London. It was a revelation. I finished that meal wanting to prostrate myself weeping, at the feet of the chef who had made it. I felt warm and airy for days afterwards. After that, I developed an intense desire to uncover the secrets of this strange, fabulous art. I transformed my student life into an extended preparation for my assault on the culinary world.
The next day, I went to the pool to learn how to dive. The instructor was very strict and he told me to do things in a certain way. I practised that manoeuvre until the hour was up. The next visit, he got me standing upright and diving off the edge. It was a lot of fun. I felt as if I was flying.

Summer promises us two great joys: escaping home and reading books. Books can help us to feel more at home in the world. We can relate our experiences to those described in great books written long ago or in distant lands. In the books of others, we find our own thoughts, embarrassments and dramas. Authors can locate words to depict a situation we thought ourselves alone in feeling, or can express our very own thoughts, but with a clarity and psychological accuracy we could not match.
We feel grateful to these strangers for reminding us of who we are. Through reading and travel, we escape the deadening effect of habit. Our eyes are never more open than during our first few days in a new place. Our mind is like a radar newly attuned to pick up certain objects floating through consciousness. Our attention is drawn to the shades of the sky, to the changeability of a face, to the hypocrisy of a friend, or to a submerged sadness about a situation that we had previously not even known we could feel sad about.

Music has become an integral part of our lives in many ways. In the past, there has been a significant increase in the opportunities to listen to music through various technologies such as radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, videos and the internet. However, there has also been a decline in the performance of live music and the full-time employment opportunities for professional musicians. Despite these challenges, music continues to play an important role in our society. It provides opportunities for numerous activities, both formal and informal. Music is also beneficial to our well-being. Studies have shown that playing an instrument can improve cognitive skills, social relationships and concentration. As a result, there is likely to be a continuing demand for instrumental teaching in the short term. In the long term, there are likely to be some changes in the way music is taught and performed. However, music will continue to play an important role in our lives.

The craft of acting can be seen as a form of expression that involves both physical and psychological elements. Actors often find themselves being criticized for their lack of professionalism or their inability to convey emotions effectively. However, there are some actors who are able to overcome these challenges and deliver powerful and memorable performances.
One such actor is Adrian Lester, who is known for his expressive and nuanced portrayal of the character Hamlet. Lester's ability to convey emotion through his body and voice is truly captivating. He is able to bring the character of Hamlet to life in a way that is both relatable and moving.
Another important aspect of acting is the relationship between the actor and the audience. The perfect theatre should make you feel as if your presence has made a difference. It's important that the audience is close enough to the actor to hear, see, and feel what is going on stage. The proportions of an auditorium are also important. They have to respond to the human voice and the scale of the human body.
When you visit the theatre, you want something done in a way you can't imagine. Otherwise, you may as well have stayed at home.

Tiredness is a common problem these days. In many countries, people are sleep deprived. Research in the USA has found that 40 million Americans are chronically affected by sleeplessness. People often cut back on sleep when they are busy. They get up too early to avoid the rush hour.
There is a sleep research laboratory in the English Midlands where people can go to learn more about sleep. The laboratory investigates the effects of fatigue on sailors, the effects of airpot noise on sleepers, and the dangers of motorway driving for flagging drivers.
It is known that humans sleep according to a daily cycle. Once asleep, they switch between four different stages of unconsciousness. When dreams occur, the brain paralyses the body except for the hands and eyelids.
However, there are some things that are not known about human sleep. For example, it is not known whether sleep repairs body tissue or restores muscles. It is also not known whether sleep rests the frontal section of the brain that controls speech and creativity.

I was in Vienna to take photographs. I was there to take pictures for a picture book. The pictures were more than my livelihood. They were part of my life. I took photographs because I loved the way light fell on a surface and the way one picture could capture the essence of a time and place.
One day, I took the perfect photograph. It was a picture of Stephansplatz in Vienna. The weather was cold and snowy. The sky was gray. The cathedral was tall and majestic. I spent a lot of time trying to capture the perfect shot. But I couldn't do it. I had to settle for something partial.
Even though I was disappointed, I was still glad I was in Vienna. I was taking photographs and I was being paid to do it. It was a good assignment.

Kinetic art is a type of art that is concerned with movement. In the twentieth century, there has been a lot of kinetic art created. The artworks that are made by kinetic artists either move by themselves or investigate the idea of movement in some way.
A new exhibition at the Hayward Gallery in London traces the history of kinetic art. The exhibition includes paintings, drawings, documents, and films on kinetic art. Visitors can enjoy the artworks without having to read a lot of text.
The exhibition is called "Kinetic Art Rejoice." It is a charmingly idiosyncratic investigation into an almost forgotten aspect of the last 60 years. The exhibition is a must-see for anyone who is interested in art or kinetic art.

Photography has been used to record all aspects of human life and activity for over a century. It has allowed us to see the fleeting moment and visualize both the vast and the minuscule. Photography has brought us images from remote areas of the world, distant parts of the solar system, and the social complexities and crises of modern life. It has also been used to document historical events.
The earliest creations of pictorial recording go back as far as the Upper Palaeolithic period of about 35,000 years ago. Pictures have been used to record events, decorate homes, and tell stories. Writing poetry is like playing a game. You need to be spontaneous and creative, but also be aware of the risks. If you try to be too perfect, you might end up making a mess of things. To write well, you need to read a lot, write a lot, and use your imagination. You can also find inspiration from your dreams and hopes. There are different ways to write poetry, but the most important thing is to find a style that works for you.
In a short story, there is no room for too many characters or long narratives. Flashbacks should be brief and only used if they help the story. Dialogue is more useful than long explanations. You need to keep the story moving and avoid overwriting.
Screenplays are like playing chess. The more you practice, the better you become. You need to be able to see the big picture and the patterns in the play. If you can see the game as a whole, you can start to see patterns and strategies.
Writing and chess are two things that have a lot in common. They both require creativity, patience, and practice. If you want to be successful at either one, you need to be willing to learn from your mistakes and keep practicing.

I have never started a novel with more worry. If I call it a novel, it is because I don't know what else to call it. I have a story to tell, but I don't end it with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave my reader in the air. This book is about my memories of a man I knew. I have little knowledge of what happened to him between the times I saw him. I could fill in the gaps, but I don't want to do that. I only want to set down what I know. To save embarrassment to people still living, I have changed the names of the people in the story. The man I am writing about is not famous. It may be that he never will be. It may be that when his life at last comes to an end, he will leave no more trace of his sojourn on earth than a stone thrown into a river leaves on the surface of the water. Then my book, if it is read at all, will be read only for what intrinsic interest it may possess. But it may be that the way of life that he has chosen for himself and the peculiar strength and sweetness of his character may have an ever-growing influence over his fellow men so that, long after his death perhaps, it may be realised that there lived in this age a very remarkable creature.

Poetry recitals are happening all the time. There are different kinds of poetry being written and different ways of presenting and reciting poetry. Some poets write poems that are meant to be read on the page, while others write poems that are meant to be recited aloud. There are also different ways to promote poetry recitals. You can attend poetry readings at schools, colleges, arts festivals, or even in your own town. If you attend a poetry reading, you can learn a lot about poetry and what poets are trying to say. However, attending a poetry reading cannot be a substitute for reading poetry on the page.

Oral History
The way historians use stories from people's memories is not always perfect. Sometimes, people's memories are not accurate or they are influenced by their feelings or beliefs. When a historian listens to someone's story, it can affect the way they write about the past. It is important for historians to accept responsibility for their part in creating new evidence.
Animal Science
There are two main ways to study animals. One way is to focus on how the body works. The other way is to study the behavior of the whole animal. Within the second way, there are two main groups of researchers. One group studies the learning abilities of a restricted range of species. The other group studies the naturally occurring, unlearnt behavior of animals.
The Social Sciences
If you are studying a social science for the first time, you will need to learn two things at the same time. You will need to learn the substance of the subject and the methodology of the subject. This means that you will need to become familiar with the knowledge and research findings which fill the textbooks, as well as the methods by which the knowledge is obtained and organized.
Classical Architecture
Classical architecture is not just about building beautiful buildings. It is also about art and aesthetics. The Romans believed that architecture should be in harmony with nature and that it should be used to express beauty and emotion. The origins of classical architecture are complex. However, the basic idea of the classical temple is simple. It is a single-roomed hut.

I read somewhere that if you dig a deep hole, you can see the stars. I asked you to help me with my plan. I climbed down the well and fell into the water. I cracked my head and was dazed. I saw strange lights and stars. I was scared and relieved. You called down and asked if I was all right. I lay still and waited for help. You called out for help and I was pulled out of the well. I was tired and scared. I ran away and hid in the shadows. My mother and father came to see me. My mother screamed and my father shouted. I was sad and ashamed. I felt like I had done something wrong. I apologized to my parents. I was punished. I was grounded. I was not allowed to go out with my friends. I was sad and lonely.

Susan was widowed and her children were grown up. She was leaving her family home. The removers were removing everything from the house. It was a lovely house that she was leaving. The years she had spent there were hanging around in the air.
When the removers started to remove the furniture, Susan was surprised. She could easily imagine if she had warned the removers about the piano. But it was too late. The piano was being carried down the stairs and out of the front door. It tipped slightly and the removers had to carry it back up the stairs.
The children were laughing and relieved that the piano was finally gone. Susan was also laughing. She was glad that she had not cried. The whole process had cost so much it was months before they could afford to have the piano professionally tuned.

The internet opened up a new way for people to share their opinions about books. A popular online bookstore called Amazon allowed anyone to write a review of a book. This made it easy for people to see what other readers thought of a book. The reviews on Amazon were free and uncensored, which meant that people could say whatever they wanted about a book. However, there were some problems with the reviews. For example, some people wrote fake reviews to promote their own books. And, some people wrote reviews that were too long or too short. Despite these problems, the reviews on Amazon were still a valuable tool for readers. They provided a remarkably accurate indication of whether or not a particular book was worth buying.

Art has changed a lot in the last two hundred years. In the past, art was praised for being unique and revolutionary. But today, we often get cold feet and say that an artist has gone too far. We expect artists to be separate from the rest of us and to have special talents and drive.
Today, artists are left to their own devices and we get rather cross with them if they want to come down out of the clouds. If an artist chooses a piece of text and writes it on a canvas, is the finished product a painting?
The artist's new show takes the daring step of swapping the pristine still lifes which have made his name for paintings of the world of the London Underground. The sketches have provided the material for Underground Encounters, an exhibition of 40 paintings and drawings which convey the curious magic of this sunken world designed for a population in transit.

My Dad was driving me back to London when he told me that I was going to get a scholarship to Oxford University. He was excited about it and he knew that I would do well. He also knew that I had ambitions to be a barrister. He was proud of me and I felt good about myself.
But my father also had some concerns. He said that I would have to do one last assignment for him, that it was the most important piece of business the family firm had ever attempted. I was worried about my final exams and I didn't want to have to think about anything else just now. But I knew that my father would be disappointed if I refused, so I agreed to do it.
I was proud of my father and his accomplishments. He was a successful businessman and he had built a successful family business. I was grateful to him for everything he had done for me.

Simon Costello knew that the purchase of the house in Pembroke Square had been a mistake. It was a possession that was only afforded by exercising stringent and calculated economy. At the time, it had seemed like a sensible and desirable move. But it had turned out to be a bad decision. The flat wasn't really suitable for a family, and they needed more room. All these things could have been achieved in a suburb or in a less fashionable part of London, but Lois was ambitious for more than additional space. She had decided that a necessary economy was for one of them to travel by public transport. Her firm was on the other side of London; obviously Simon must be the one to economise. The overcrowded tube journey was a mood of envious resentment and brooding. He remembered his grandfather's house and his grandmother's advice. He knew that his job was important to his wife and to them both. If he had been able to leave earlier, the encounter wouldn't have taken place. He felt guilty and ashamed of himself.

I chose this place to live because I thought I would find anonymity. But it was not to be. People in the shops started to recognize me. The roses in my neighbor's garden were once loved. Usually, I stay inside, but tonight, I am watching the swifts flying. I have cut back rosemary and lemon balm to make a space for a chair. It is a narrow London garden. My upstairs neighbor, Jaz, is leaning out of the window. She is a writer. I have a copy of her latest manuscript. We talk for a while. I give her some advice about her writing. She is not happy with my advice. But I don't mind. I have my own life. I go to work and I have a social life. I also like to read books. When I go home, I feel calm.

Heritage gives people and communities a sense of connection to the past. It is important for understanding and interpreting our individual and national futures. Heritage represents a fundamental desire for continuity. It affects everything from customs to material culture.
There are aspects of your national heritage that you may not like or condone, but it is yours, and it is reassuring to feel a part of something.
Museums exist to facilitate an encounter with authenticity. They present items that actually existed - were used - had meaning - at some historical time.
Architecture and Environment
The desire to preserve things is not new. Change in our towns comes with such speed and on such a scale that most of us are affected by it in some way. If there is a psychological need for preservation it is part of the planners job to take account of it.

Albert Einstein was a famous scientist who developed some mysterious theories about the universe. His theories are called relativity and are famous for being difficult to understand. Einstein made a big contribution to science by looking at the nature of time, space, matter and energy.
Previously, people had described the universe using Isaac Newton's ideas. Newton believed that time and space were absolute. Einstein disagreed with this idea and said that time and space were relative.
Young readers, Lydia and I, used to distrust prize-winning books because we thought they would be boring. Our father would give us money to read books and sometimes he would put a book in our presents that he thought we would like.
Language is a fascinating subject. It is difficult to understand the origin of language, but it is important to learn about it. Language probably developed in East Africa a long time ago. It was used for friendly interaction and power struggles.

Writing reviews is a skilled and multi-faceted job. It is one thing to write a short review for a newspaper, and quite another to write a long review for an international journal. The reviewer needs to think about the probable audience, the length of the review, and the subject matter. They also need to know quite a bit about quite a number of things and be able to write prose that intelligent people can understand and enjoy.
However, reviewing is not a primary occupation. It is something you can only do well enough if you are also doing something else well enough.

Ralph unlocked his flat door and entered the dark hall. He felt a sense of ownership when he returned home alone at the end of the day. His flat had been waiting for him, and he was grateful that it was still intact. He had grown impatient with its inability to be transformed. There was a small puddle of letters and a red eye of the answering machine that sometimes gathered by the door. He would often read or listen to music as the night deepened outside.
One evening, Ralph was sitting at his desk, feeling lonely. He was grateful that he had a place to call home, but he also felt that he was missing something. He felt powerless and unable to find his purpose in life. He had tried to formulate a plan for his own betterment, but he had been unsuccessful. He had applied for jobs and latched himself wearily on to his peers' futures. He had attended his only interview and was offered the job. He was relieved to have pulled off twenty minutes of pleasant conversation with his boss.

I was going to witness goat racing on Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. There was a lot of people and things around me, but I managed to get a good spot. The racecourse was not very big, but it was similar to other racecourses. The goats were being kept in order. It was difficult to control the goats because they eat a lot.
As the day was ending, I started to think about the night ahead. There was no place to sleep and we hadn't seen any villages or huts since early morning. It was dark and we couldn't see very well. We put in new batteries for our torch, but they didn't work. We couldn't find a place to camp. After a while, we saw a light and our hopes went up. The light was the moonlight shining on the waves. We couldn't see what was happening, but we heard the sound of the water rushing. Time stood still and we moved on.

There are some activities that take a long time to complete. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you are impatient and add the oil too quickly, the mayonnaise will curdle. If you start tugging with frustration on a tangled fishing line, the knot will just become tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some functions are performed very quickly, while others take much longer. Some can be speeded up, but others cannot. If you try to rush a task, it will probably break down.
There are also different ways to think. Some people think quickly and make decisions right away. Others think more slowly and carefully. There is a type of thinking that is called 'intellect'. This type of thinking involves figuring out problems and making decisions. There is also another type of thinking that is called 'creativity'. This type of thinking involves coming up with new ideas and solutions.

I have been welcomed warmly to a sociable and well-provisioned place in a very isolated area. There are a lot of people living there, but I don't have much trouble communicating. My school French is good enough to get me by, but I miss the nuances and my phrasebook is not very helpful. There was a problem with self-confidence at first, but I'm doing better now. I still have some problems when people talk to me, but I'm trying to be more positive.
When I first met Elliot, I was a young author and he didn't notice me. But I became successful as a playwright and now Elliot treats me better. We see each other more often.
Alfred Hitchcock was a film director who cared about the technical ingredients of his films. He believed that people are aroused by pure film, irrespective of their cultural background. Therefore, if a picture is designed correctly, the audience should react the same way. Hitchcock's self-appraisal was always precise and rational. He was a man of reason and a craftsman of genius who liked to hear an audience scream.

Astronomy has changed a lot in the past 50 years. There were not many charts and catalogues before, and telescopic equipment was limited. Today, there are many more charts and telescopes available. Computers have made it easier to produce charts and analyze observations. All this makes it a good time for amateur astronomy.
However, there has also been a loss. The skies are not as clear as they used to be. There are a lot of aircraft condensation trails that can make it difficult to see the sun or stars.
Society is also changing. There are too many things to do and too much choice. This can be stressful. People are looking for ways to simplify their lives.
McAndrews Hotel is a family tradition that has been going on for many years. It is a special place where people can relax and enjoy themselves.

Othello, a play by Shakespeare, was recently transferred to London from Stratford. The production is exceptional and allows me to make amends for an unfair review I wrote last spring. I complained that the actor Ray Fearon was too young to play the title role, but I think it's a distortion of the tragedy to remove the age difference between Othello and Desdemona. However, I appreciate Mr Fearon's magnificent performance. The whole cast is magnificent, and there are many memorable scenes in the play.
Lake Vostok is a hidden freshwater lake in Antarctica. It is covered by a thick layer of ice and has been isolated from air and sunlight for millions of years. Scientists are excited to explore Lake Vostok and discover what strange organisms live there.
Scientists were talking on the radio about why they become scientists. They said that it is because of their desire to understand everything from the atom to the black hole. But they also said that it is more important to know whether what scientists are doing is right, rather than get bogged down in debates over the point of it all.

There is a special connection between people and food. Cooking is a satisfying and rewarding experience that can bring joy to both adults and children. It is also a way to share our creativity and love. When we cook, we are offering our own creations to others. Sharing food is a powerful symbol of our deepest human needs and it is often the centerpiece of our celebrations.
This morning, Alistair had a lot of paperwork to deal with. He had a lot of tax forms and other paperwork to file. He also had a lot of books and journals to organize. As he rode the elevator, he knew that his girlfriend, Mallory, would be on time for their appointment. She is very organized and she is always on time.
Karen had a desire not to be like her mother. She created her own story and mythology. In her story, there were significant moments in her progress. One day, she was hit in the eye by a golf club. But she was saved by the bone in her eye. She knew that she was saved for some purpose.
Miss Fogerty was excited and saddened by the scene she had just witnessed. She was excited to be the first to know something of note, but she was also saddened by the doctor's condition. The doctor has been her doctor for many years and she remembered with gratitude his concern for her annual bouts of laryngitis.

Joanna MacGregor is a concert pianist who has a busy schedule. She has added the task of writing books for young children learning the piano. Even though she is very busy, she still finds time to help children learn the piano.
One day, Joanna gave a concert for kids. There was a young boy who was not impressed by her performance. He asked her to play "Match of the Day." Joanna was surprised, but she agreed to play. She played the song and the boy was very happy.
Joanna is passionate about helping children learn the piano. She has written her own elementary piano tutor for children. She also runs her own recording label and has collaborated with many artists.
Joanna believes that everyone should be able to learn the piano. She says that learning should be unadulterated fun. She also believes that practice is the most important factor.

Writing by hand and on screen, Dr Johnson said that writing without effort is generally read without pleasure. Good writing comes hard. Looking back at my handwritten school essays, I was surprised at how few crossings-out they contained. Today I would have rewritten them five times over. The slowness of the hand disciplined the brain. The casual facility of the computer leads to sloppiness. Most writers using word processors find the time spent correcting early drafts more or less equates with the time originally spent on handwritten text.
Books versus Electronic Text
Reading anything lengthy on a screen is such a miserable experience that most never do it. What is new is not so much the branchings of electronic text as that computers don't invite the joined-up thinking of reading anything in its entirety.

You don't take sugar, do you? The secretary shouted this as a fact. She had been making coffee for many months. She forgot to give him sugar because she thought he wasn't supposed to be there. But nowadays he was always there. He had discovered that if he stayed away, people would start to invite him to everything. She gave him a folder with a book label on it. The book label said: 'A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert.' She did not want to see the word 'synopsis'. She had already read a synopsis of this book. She was not interested in seeing another one. The book was not finished yet. It would take a long time to finish. The book was not very well-written. It was like a lost conviction. The author was famous, but he was not very productive. He was difficult to deal with. He was like a general with a million tons of equipment pinned down on the beach by nothing except an excess of opportunity.

In England, breakfast is an important meal according to health experts. It is not a very old meal in England. There are some references to people having breakfast in the Middle Ages, but most people did not have breakfast unless they were royalty or wealthy. However, in the sixteenth century, breakfast became more common. This is because there was more food available and people often started working very early. As a result, people needed to have breakfast in order to be able to work.

When a photographer takes a photograph, they choose visual information that is determined by their technical and aesthetic skills, personal views and experience. The photograph can be seen as a representation of the photographer's point of view or as a symbol of a state of affairs in the world. Sport has taught me personal discipline and determination, but it can also teach you the benefits of working as one of a team. It's very much like life - you can succeed as an individual, but you must never forget there are others around you. Some experiences are so memorable that they form islands of clarity in our recollection. For me, such a momentous occasion took place one night in California many years ago, when I lay awake listening to the beautiful sounds of a mockingbird singing.

Love them, fear them, worship them, human culture has always had a lot to say about birds. Birds have been part of British culture for a long time. In the past, people used to read the directions in which wrens flew to determine their luck. Today, the image of the wren is still in pictures and ceramics in many British households.
Birds are also important to us because they are indicators of environmental change. Conservationists in Britain cite the endangering of 30 species, which is a big loss of cultural heritage. Folklore is important because it can help us to understand and appreciate birds. The stories, legends and rhymes which persist through time can summon up feelings and attitudes from a consciousness buried under all the stuff of modern life.

A map is used to show the relations of points and features on the Earth's surface. It is determined by distance and direction. In the past, distance was often measured in units of time, but such measurements did not give much information about the actual distance. Direction is also an important element of a map, but for the ordinary traveller, it was not the most important thing. Written itineraries used to be popular for a long time, but maps are still used today. Certain types of maps, such as those showing railway systems, do not always show true directions. Landmarks along a route were sometimes indicated by signs. The history of cartography is the history of the increase in the accuracy and comprehensiveness of maps. Cartography has called in other sciences to its aid, such as terrestrial magnetism and astronomy. The development of new technologies has also improved the accuracy and comprehensiveness of maps. Maps are a valuable record for the students of man's past.

I was invited to a young man's drawing room, which was like an oasis of cultured sanity. There was a lot of music and pictures in the room. The young man's name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had won a scholarship to Oxford University to read history. He had a lot of records and a stereo player. He also had a lot of ambition. He wanted to become a composer. I also had a lot of ambition. I wanted to become a pop star. We had similar ambitions. But my dreams were not life or death to me. They might have become so had I failed. When Andrew suggested a new ambition for me, I had no qualms about giving it a go. We wrote some music together. We parted ways, promising to meet again. I was still more interested in the charts than in the West End theatre. But I knew that I had met somebody of rare ability and determination. I would be mad to miss out on being a sidekick to a chap who was clearly going to take the musical theatre by storm.

Language is a powerful tool that humans use to communicate and express themselves. It is an instinct that people have, like spiders spinning webs. Climate and weather, which are created by the air around us, also have a big impact on our lives. They can affect the distribution of animals and plants. For example, warm and wet climates allow the growth of tropical jungles, which are full of different species. Cold and windy areas have fewer living things. The weather patterns that make up the climate are caused by air rising and mixing. Some of the air movement is due to the Earth's rotation. The sun is another important source of air movement. Coffee is a popular drink that people often order in restaurants. Making a good cup of coffee is not easy. It takes time and practice to learn the art and science of making coffee.

Art on TV is not very successful at showing paintings and sculptures. It could be because the camera does not always have the ability to show the details of a work of art. There are few series on television that have managed to convey both the pleasure and complexity of looking at paintings and sculptures.
Dealing in Metals is a risky business. It is regulated less than other markets and there is a lot of risk involved. But it can also be very profitable.
Abaco is a beautiful island in the Bahamas. It is known as 'The Sailing Capital of the World'. There are many things to do on Abaco, including sailing, fishing, diving, snorkelling and swimming.

The Bamboo Bike Club offers a course where you can build your own bike. It's a fun and rewarding experience that will teach you how to select bamboo for strength, form strong joints, and assemble the frame.
The course is held in Hackney Wick, east London, and lasts for a weekend. You will learn how to cut bamboo, assemble the frame, and wrap it with hemp bindings. The finished bike is strong and lightweight, and it can be customized to your own preferences.
The cost of the course is less than £500, and it includes all the tools and materials you need to build your bike. You can also purchase a bike frame separately if you want.

Self-help books are popular in New York publishing. There is a self-help book that is very popular. It is about how to bridge communication gaps between the sexes. The book is written by a psychologist and it has sold millions of copies.
There are a lot of self-help books published every year. But only a few are actually good. If you want to write a self-help book, you need to make sure that your writing is clear and concise. You also need to make sure that your argument is strong.
Another important thing to remember when writing a self-help book is to never write down to your reader. If you do that, your book will be dead.

There is a cool air at Cannons Gym, a popular lunch-time spot for workers in the City of London. The air-conditioning is so strong that the gym feels like a cold place, like the Arctic. People often overuse air-conditioning, but there are other ways to cool buildings. They could use natural light and ventilation, thicker walls, and other methods. These measures would reduce the need for air-conditioning.
Sundials are instruments used to measure time. They were once important, but now they are mostly used as garden ornaments. People are starting to use sundials again because they are romantic and calming objects.
My image of china-painting came from a visit to an arts and crafts exhibition. The ladies demonstrated how to paint flowers on a teacup. The painting was perfect, and it was easy to learn. I wondered what kind of people would have the courage to enrol on a china-painting course. In fact, the atmosphere was friendly and relaxed. Everyone was there to have fun.

The Wrong Country Uncle chose a package holiday for them at a very reasonable price. They booked a flight from Gatwick Airport to Venice, the fairyland city. But something went wrong. They ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, somewhere in Switzerland.
When they arrived at the hotel, they were greeted by a woman who introduced herself as Mrs. Franks. She was in charge of the holiday. She explained that they had booked the wrong group. There was a problem with the booking. They were meant to be in Venice, but they ended up in Switzerland.
Mrs. Franks offered to explain everything to them. She said that there are many different holidays that Your-Kind-of-Holiday sends its clients to. She also said that the tickets and labels are naturally similar.
Keith was not satisfied. He tried to go over in his mind every single thing that had occurred. He was tired and fatigued. He walked out of the reception area and Dawne followed him. They didn't say to one another that there was an irony in the catastrophe that had occurred.

Ernest Shackleton was a famous explorer who lived in the 20th century. He was known for his bravery and leadership. People in America have only recently discovered Shackleton. There are many books and movies about his life.
Shackleton was a very successful manager. He was able to lead his team to many achievements. He was also a good communicator. He was able to motivate his team to work hard and achieve their goals.
One of Shackleton's most famous accomplishments was his expedition to the South Pole in 1908. He was able to lead his team to within 97 miles of the South Pole. However, the weather was bad and the supplies ran out. Shackleton had to make a difficult decision. He decided to turn back.
Shackleton was a leader who was always in charge. He was able to motivate his team to work hard and achieve their goals. He was also able to adapt to changing circumstances. He was a model for managers and leaders.

In the forests of Madagascar, there lives a primate called the aye-aye. The aye-aye is like a woodpecker. It bores through wood and probes cavities beneath the surface to find insect larvae. The aye-aye uses its incisor teeth to gnaw its way in and its narrow, elongated third finger to probe and scoop.
Scientists have discovered how the aye-aye locates the insects hidden inside the wood. They found that the aye-aye can sense the cavity itself. When searching for food, an aye-aye taps the surface of the wood with its middle finger and brings its exceptionally large ears forward, focusing them at a point in front of its nose. It can probably also hear the rustle of insects, which might move when disturbed by the tapping from above.

Most people have photographs of their grandparents, but not many of us know what their lives were like. We often intend to write things down, but never get round to it. We may leave videos rather than photographs, but the images will remain two-dimensional. Hannah Renier has come up with an answer: she writes other people's autobiographies. She writes a hardback book of at least 20,000 words - with illustrations if required - a chronicle not of the famous, but of the ordinary.
The book involves up to 30 hours of taped interviews which Ms Renier uses as the basis to write the life story. She organises her material logically and writes well, the final content is as good as its subject. The book carries a price tag of nearly PS3,000, with extra copies at PS25 each.

The University Museum of Classical Archaeology has a collection of casts of Greek and Roman sculpture. The sculptures are replicas of the originals and are housed in a purpose-built gallery. The museum also has a collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks and minerals.
Cambridge Darkroom is a centre for photography with community darkrooms and a gallery. They offer courses and workshops for people of all ages and abilities. Members can use the darkrooms and young photographers can develop their skills with the Young Members scheme.
The Sedgwick Museum of Geology has a collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks and minerals. The museum also has a collection of Britain's oldest intact geological collection.
The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs has a large collection of air photographs. The photographs are of considerable general interest as a detailed, year-by-year record of the landscape.
Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre is a centre where you can create wall hangings by rubbing brass plates off tombs of medieval knights and ladies.

From here to paternity, I have been blessed with 35 years of small children. I have loved every minute of it. I had the pleasure of feeding the baby this morning and that for me is what being a father is all about. I'm terribly lucky with my children. We all love the same things: opera, theatre, books, music. It creates a great bond.
I have been a father for many years. I have made some mistakes, but I have always tried to be there for my children. If they need me, I'm here. I'm always on the basis that they ring me.
I also have a lot of other experiences as a father. I have been through a lot of things with my children, from their first concerts to their sports days. I'm sad that I missed some of those things, but there are compensations now, like being able to take them on holidays to the south of France.

Marlowe's epic play, Tamburlaine the Great, is a thrilling night of the year. It is a long play, but it is worth seeing. The acting is excellent, and the staging is impressive.

It is a delightful new musical that is perfect for a family night out. Another play is The Merry Wives of Windsor by William Shakespeare. It is a farcical comedy that is perfect for a night of laughter.
If you are looking for a night out at the theatre, there are a few great options to choose from this season. So, go see a play and enjoy the show!

Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game when they find out that one of their customers is her Uncle Jim. He tries to manipulate her affection for him and alienate her from her friends. When Emma finds her life in danger, things get dark and compelling.
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, join forces to investigate a train accident that happened in 1915. They work hard to understand what happened and why.
Mary Dyer doesn't fit into her family or male-dominated culture. She loves her father's racing pigeons and knows enough to carry on managing the loft and winning prizes.
Robert Westall uses the viewpoint of a mature woman for this chilling story of rural prejudice and persecution. Rose feels just as dismayed by the methodical ruthlessness of her teenage son.
Someone's Mother is Missing is a story about two teenagers, Sam and Lisa, who gain a better sense of reality and the value of family through their relationship.
Stanley's Aquarium is a story about a first-person narrator who finds a job gardening for elderly Stanley. The book takes a 'thrillerish' twist without losing its sharp insight into character and relationships.

Science flying in the face of gravity. Journalist Tom Mumford joined students using weightlessness to test their theories. It looked like just another aircraft from the outside. The pilot told his young passengers that it was built in 1964, a Boeing KC-135 refuelling tanker, based on the Boeing 707 passenger craft. The students were in for the flight of their lives. Inside, it had become a long white tunnel. There were almost no windows, but it was eerily illuminated by lights along the padded walls. Most of the seats had been ripped out, apart from a few at the back, where the pale-faced, budding scientists took their places. The flight was smooth and the students were excited. They floated aimlessly and danced in the air. It was an unforgettable experience for all of the students.

I planted trees in New Zealand. I had a lot of winters there. My parents bought a small plot of land and I started planting trees in 1968. It rained a lot that year. I had a guy to help me plant the trees. It was hard work, but I enjoyed it. I also wrote my first book there. The connection between me and that area is still immensely strong.

Six years ago, my husband Derek and I turned our dairy farm in Somerset into an 'open farm' and have been looking after orphaned animals ever since. One day, I was surprised to see a cardboard box being canned towards me. It contained three small grey badger cubs. Their coats were like velvet and their eyes looked up at me from three tiny black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. They were healthy and well but they were cold and whimpering. I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and installed them beside the stove for warmth.
The cubs grew quickly and started to eat from a bottle. After a few days, they were feeding every four hours. Within a week, they had progressed to drinking from a bottle and were moving around, albeit shakily. With each other for company and a heated pad as a substitute 'mum', they seemed very contented.
However, fate took a turn for the worse. One of the cubs, Willow, became lethargic and died. I was heartbroken. But fate worked in strange ways. Six days later, I found another male cub, Willow II, who had been abandoned by his mother. I took him in and he joined the fold.
The cubs grew and thrived. They were eating cereals for breakfast, a meat and vegetable meal for lunch and fruit and nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs and sunflower seeds in the evening. They were very active and would go for walks at dusk or late at night.
One day, I spotted some odder badgers in our field. They were probably looking for food. We were warned that they would climb into our badger pen and kill the cubs, so I placed sheet metal over the gate to make it as inaccessible as possible.
We started an appeal to build a sett on the farm for the badgers to move into. With the help of local firms and a bus company, we were able to raise enough money to build the sett. The badgers moved into their new home and are doing well.

Sir Edmund Halley was a famous astronomer who lived in the 17th century. He is best known for his comet that bears his name. One of his greatest accomplishments was to chart the variations of the compass. These variations are now known as declination. Without declination, sailors were unable to correct their compasses and navigate the oceans.
Halley planned a trip to the Cape Verde Islands to chart declination. However, his trip was aborted because of crew insubordination. He returned to the seas a second time and published a chart of declination in 1701. This chart was used by sailors for many years.
Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, is planning to retrace Halley's voyage. He wants to commemorate Halley's accomplishments and also collect scientific data. The expedition will involve making measurements that Halley made, but with far more precise instruments. The data collected should help to refine the existing mathematical model of Earth's magnetic field.

Peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their magnificent trains to the hens. They re-enact the mystery that tormented Charles Darwin to his dying day. Darwin argued that living creatures came to be the way they are by evolution, rather than by special creation. He believed that the fittest would generally mean toughest, swiftest, cleverest, and most alert. But the peacocks tail was at best a waste of space and in practice a severe encumbrance.
The zoologist Marion Petrie and her colleagues are now exploiting the quasi-wild conditions of Whipsnade to try to settle the matter. They have identified two main questions. First, is the premise correct - do peahens really choose the males with the showiest trains? And, secondly, do the peacocks with the showiest trains have some extra, genuinely advantageous quality, as Wallace supposed, or is it really all show, as Darwin felt?
The mature cocks display in groups at a number of sites around Whipsnade, and the hens judge one against the other. Long observation from hides, backed up by photographs, suggests that the hens really do like the showiest males. What seems to count is the number of eye-spots on the train, which is related to its length.

In the past few million years, humans and chimpanzees have not had much time to develop differences. We are still more than 98% identical to chimps. Our physical capacity for making art and anything else we consider uniquely human must be due to a small number of genes.
Modern studies of animal behaviour have shown that many similarities exist between humans and animals. For example, tools are used not only by humans but also by wild chimpanzees and sea otters. Monkeys also have a simple one-word language.
As for art, the earliest forms of human art may have been wood carvings or body painting. But if they were, we wouldn't know it, because those materials don't get preserved. Not until the Cro-Magnons, beginning around 35,000 years ago, do we have unequivocal evidence for a distinctly human art.
There are some differences between human art and animal activities. Human art is non-utilitarian, it's made for aesthetic pleasure and it's transmitted by learning rather than by genes. But these differences don't seem to be fatal. Even some human art that later became famous was created by artists for their private satisfaction.

International voluntary work, also known as volunteer tourism, can have both positive and negative impacts. Volunteering can also lead to greater international understanding, conflict resolution, and democratic participation. However, if volunteering is limited to individuals of means from wealthier areas of the world, it may not benefit people and communities who currently lack access to international voluntary work.
At its worst, international volunteering can be exploitative or self-serving. At its best, it can bring benefits to individual volunteers and the organisations they work for, as well as provide space for an exchange of technical skills, knowledge, and cross-cultural experience.
Volunteer tourism can also be seen as a way to help others. However, it is important to be aware of the potential negative impacts of volunteer tourism, such as the bypassing of democratic processes and the reduction of development to individual acts of charity.

Advertising is not doing well. It started to decline early in 1989, well before the recession really began to bite. The main problem with advertising is that it has not been able to keep up with the pace of economic change. As a result, most people do not buy most of the brands they see advertised.

Solar Survivor Charles Clover ventures inside Britain's most environmentally-friendly home, Southwell in Nottinghamshire. The house is full of surprises. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their sewage into garden compost and heat their house with waste heat from electrical appliances and their own body heat. The house is super-insulated, with krypton-filled triple-glazed windows, which means that you do not hear a sound inside. Once inside and with your shoes off, there is a monastic stillness. The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, were serious about the environment long before it hit the political agenda. They wrote a book on green architecture back in the 1970s, The Autonomous House. They designed composting earth closets, lowered rainwater tanks into the cellar, and specified copper gutters to protect the drinking water. The house is cheap to build and easy to maintain.

The camera can lie. Arthur Conan Doyle, the creator of the Sherlock Holmes stories, believed himself to be a rational man and a scientist. But in 1920, he thought he was seeing scientific proof that fairies really existed. He published photographs alongside an article he wrote, acknowledging fairies as supernatural wonders. It was not until 1939 that the two ladies who took the photos admitted these were fake. They simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and arranged them among flowers. The results are undeniably beautiful. But the simplicity of the trick undermines a basic principle of photography, that the camera cannot lie. Today, we are used to computer software enabling us to rework our digital images. It is a myth that photography ever had a true age of innocence. From the moment cameras began capturing reality, that reality was being altered.
