One movie that is very impressive is A Abyss Long Before Titanic. It is a Cold War thriller about oil riggers and navy experts trying to rescue a nuclear submarine stranded many miles beneath water. The movie has a lot of action and suspense.
Another movie that is very impressive is The Thin Red Line. It is a war movie about the battle for Guadalcanal. The movie has a lot of action and drama.
A third movie that is worth seeing is On Guard. It is a swashbuckler movie about a group of musketeers. The movie has a lot of action and adventure.
A fourth movie that is worth seeing is Character. It is a dark and brooding movie about a bailiff and his son. The movie has a lot of atmosphere and suspense.
A fifth movie that is worth seeing is The Good, the Bad and the Ugly. It is a spaghetti western movie about the American West. The movie has a lot of action and drama.

Steve Martin's book, "Compelling Evidence," is a compelling read. The narrator, a lawyer, finds himself defending his boss's wife when she is tried for her husband's murder. The trial scenes are exciting and the book has a surprising twist at the end.
Another book, "Curtains for the Cardinal," is also a good read. It is a historical novel about a charismatic Italian troubleshooter who gets involved in a lot of trouble. The plot is complex and the book is long, but it is still a great read.
A third book, "File Under: Deceased," introduces a new detective named Leah Hunter. Leah is a tax inspector who is very good at solving crimes. The book is a mystery and it is full of suspense.
These are just a few of the books that Steve Martin has written. They are all entertaining and well-written.

I'm 34 years old and I'm nervous about backpacking. I've done it before, but I've been busy with my job and relationship. I decided to quit my job and rent out my flat to go travelling in South East Asia for a year.
There are a lot of reasons why people are travelling in their late twenties and thirties. Some people want to disentangle themselves from their lives and head off to foreign climes. Others want to have a final fling before settling down. And still others want to get rid of their old approach to life and start over.
There are also a number of factors that make it easier to travel in your late twenties and thirties. There's a much more flexible workforce today, and there are more people working on short-term contracts. Larger companies are even adopting career-break policies.
I'm excited about the next 12 months. I'm going to be able to take satisfaction in having grabbed life by the horns. And I'm sure I speak for all of us ageing backpackers.

The home office of Georgina McGuiness had changed a lot since she had taken a break from journalism. She was able to transform the family home into an efficient workplace. She had a lot of trouble learning to use the computer, but she persevered and eventually she was able to learn the basic skills she needed. The computer has helped her to be more organized and efficient, and it has also made it easier for her to research stories and get on-line with the Internet. However, there are also some challenges associated with working from home, such as isolation and distractions. Despite these challenges, McGuiness is confident that she can continue to work from home and achieve her goals.

The Tartan Museum is a modern museum in Scotland. It has a lot of interesting objects. The museum is located in Edinburgh, a historic city. The building is very impressive. It has a huge, yellow sandstone tower and cheese-wedge buildings.
The museum has a lot of exhibitions. There are stories about the history of Scotland. There is also a children's Discovery Centre. The Discovery Centre has a lot of hands-on activities for children.
The museum is open to the public. You can visit the museum and see the objects. You can also learn about the history of Scotland.

The end of print may take some time. It's a calming concept. Change can be frightening and challenging, but it also means going from somewhere to somewhere else. Newspapers are facing a decline in sales, but their websites are growing. The decline in print sales is happening in the West, but Asia is making up the difference. Books are also changing. Kindle and similar e-readers are booming, but booksellers found that sales of physical books have only decreased slightly. There are a lot of factors that are affecting the decline of print sales, including timing, demography, geography, and the rise of digital advertising. However, print is still a crucial tool in selling internet subscriptions and raising advertising rates.

People are the most interesting subjects to photograph. A photograph with someone in it is usually more compelling than the same shot without the human interest. To photograph people well, you have to be conscious of actions, gestures and expressions. You also need to be aware of the camera's effect on these.
To photograph people effectively, you should follow these steps:
1. Group people in a way that is visually appealing.
2. Help your subject relax and find a comfortable position.
3. Avoid making it seem like you are taking a picture when you are not.
4. Make eye contact with your subject and ask them to look into the lens.
5. Use expressions and gestures to convey the subject's mood.
6. Consider the background and environment to add interest and information to the picture.
7. Include interaction between people in the picture.
8. Take pictures of people in their natural environment.
9. Decide whether you want to pose or not pose your subject.

Sarah Janson is an artist who creates illusions of reality through her paintings. She is not interested in being known as the artist who created the work, but rather the artist who made the work. Janson has been painting trompe-l'oeil for sixteen years and has a string of major corporate and private commissions behind her. Much of her work is inspired by architecture or made for architectural settings.
When Janson finishes a painting, she often feels that she has not done it justice. She is also brutally honest about her 'failings' and is frank about her mathematical abilities. Despite her inclination to play down her talent, Janson is constantly busy. She is generous in praise of her clients and is always willing to listen to their ideas.

In today's workplace, emotional intelligence (EQ) is becoming increasingly important. It is the ability to understand and manage your own emotions and the emotions of others. EQ includes basic elements such as self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social adeptness.
There are many benefits to having high EQ. For example, it can help you to be more successful in your job, improve your relationships with colleagues, and make you a more effective leader.
More and more businesses are seeing the value of EQ and are incorporating it into their management philosophy. If you want to be successful in today's workplace, you need to develop your EQ skills.

**
The media can earn money from content they don't own. Social media has made it easier to capture newsworthy events. Sometimes, journalists use images from social media to report on news stories. Unfortunately, some reporters have published UGC (user-generated content) without permission. There is a debate about whether this is ethical. Research shows that a lot of people film or photograph news events. This means that UGC has a big part to play in the future of the media. To keep the public's trust, the media needs to take steps to ensure that people are properly rewarded for their work and that permission is always sought.

Ancient Chinese medicine, also known as acupuncture, is a traditional Chinese system of medicine that has been used for centuries. It is used to treat many different conditions, but acupuncture's role in treating pain has been the most popular.
Acupuncture points are located along meridians, which are lines of energy that flow through the body. When the flow of energy is disrupted, the body becomes unbalanced and can become weak or sick.
To treat pain, acupuncturists use fine needles that are inserted into the skin at specific points on the meridians. They may also use warmth from smouldering herbs or pressure at points on the meridians.
Acupuncture can be effective for treating a variety of pain conditions, including back pain, arthritis, headaches, and migraines. It is also sometimes used to treat other conditions, such as menstrual pain and facial nerve pain.
If you are considering acupuncture for pain relief, it is important to find a qualified acupuncturist. You should also discuss your condition with your doctor to see if acupuncture is right for you.

P. D. James, a best-selling crime writer, is known for her intricate and brilliant imagination. She is a quiet and modest person, but her books are read avidly by millions worldwide.
James was born in Oxford and grew up mainly in Cambridge. She met her husband, a student at the university, and had two daughters. Her life has been hard, even tragic at times, but she has persevered and achieved great success.
James worked full-time in administration for the National Health Service and made good use of her organizational skills. She also became 'quite accustomed' to seeing corpses while working in forensic science. But it was not fascination with death itself that inspired her. It was the shape and construction involved in writing a crime novel that appealed to her.
James believes that writing detective stories is a way of bringing order out of disorder. The solution of a crime confirms the sanctity of life, even if that life is unlovable.

The pen is mightier than the psychoanalyst. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is accepted as a genuine science in many countries. It can be used to indicate certain illnesses, such as heart disease and cancer, and can reveal psychological states and emotional disturbances.
Handwriting can also be used for vocational guidance and as an adjunct to interviews. Many big companies now employ graphologists to analyse the handwriting of potential candidates for key jobs. But most doctors and psychiatrists remain dubious about the value of graphology.
A professional graphologist, Patricia Marne, argues that they should take it more seriously. She believes that handwriting can indicate psychological characteristics as well as certain medical conditions. She says: 'Handwriting is a powerful indicator of social class and intelligence. But more than that, it can be used to assess mental ability and potential, whether a person should concentrate on arts or sciences, and whether they have a devious or open character.'

Is your office working ok? Fresh air and comfortable chairs are the key to a happy, healthy workforce, according to a new survey. We went to four different offices to find out how healthy and happy they were as working environments.
In Office A, the team of seven people have created a happy, homely working environment. They adapt to the changing seasons by opening doors and roof panels or switching on electric radiators.
In Office B, the office is comfortable and well-maintained, but it lacks personality. The walls are bare and the environment is impersonal.
In Office C, the office is very busy and has a lot of activity. However, the air quality and the desks are not ideal.
In Office D, the office is very dusty and uncomfortable. The furniture is old and the space is cluttered.
The survey found that fresh air and comfortable chairs are the key to a happy, healthy workforce.

Chewing gum is a popular fashion accessory in the United States. Americans chew a lot of gum, with an estimated 12 million sticks being chewed daily. Gum is made from a variety of ingredients, including pine resins, softeners, and flavourings. The ancient Greeks and American colonists chewed a gum-like resin obtained from trees. Modern chewing gum has its origins in the late 1860s with the discovery of chicle, a milky substance obtained from the sapodilla tree. Today, chewing gum is mostly made synthetically. As the chewing gum market has grown, manufacturers have turned to synthetics to reduce costs and meet demands.

The Ghanerao Hotel in India and the Hermitage Hotel in New Zealand are two charming hotels that offer a peaceful escape. The Ghanerao Hotel is located in a small village surrounded by hills. It has a simple atmosphere and provides basic amenities. The Hermitage Hotel is situated in a stunning natural setting high up in the mountains. It offers breathtaking views and luxurious accommodations.
The Paradis Hotel on Mauritius is another peaceful retreat. It is isolated on its own peninsula and offers a private beach. The Ladera Hotel in St. Lucia is known for its dramatic setting and colonial style. The Splendid Hotel in Istanbul is a historic hotel with a unique atmosphere. The Chateau d'Etoges in France is a beautiful chateau surrounded by a moat. The Fairview Hotel in Kenya is a comfortable and affordable hotel that offers a peaceful atmosphere and stunning views. The Hotel Splendido in Italy is a historic hotel that has been frequented by many famous people.
These are just a few of the many charming hotels that can be found around the world. Each hotel offers its unique charm and personality, and they all provide a memorable experience for travelers.

The hotel inspector Sue Brown judges hotels for a living. One day, she was inspecting the Globe Hotel. Things were not going well from the beginning. The receptionist was not paying attention to the guest and the room was not clean. There was also a problem with the plumbing. Sue was not happy with the service at the hotel. She gave the hotel manager some suggestions for how to improve the service. The manager was grateful for Sue's help. He said that he would look forward to seeing her again.

Seven Up Mountaineer Doug Scott shares his experience of conquering the highest peak on each continent, the Seven Summits. My quest to climb the Seven Summits came late in life. I climbed the Seven Summits in the order I completed them.
A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)
I climbed Mt. Everest with my climbing partner, Dougal Haston. We were in a snow cave below the summit when I started talking to my feet. The cold was getting into my feet and I recalled other climbers who had lost fingers and toes from frostbite.
B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)
I climbed Mt. McKinley with Dougal Hatton. It was a treacherous mountain and the air pressure was lower than at sea level. We spent a lot of time on the mountain and we were both suffering.
C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,89Sm)
I climbed Kilimanjaro with Paul Braithwaite. It was a long and difficult climb. We got lost in the jungles and ran out of water. We eventually found a rock pool and climbed the summit.
D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)
I climbed Aconcagua with my wife, Sharu. It was a relatively easy climb. We joined a large group of people and climbed the summit.
E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)
I climbed Vinson Massif with a team of people. It was a difficult climb and the weather was extreme. We reached the summit but the visibility was poor.
F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)
I climbed Elbrus with a team of people. It was a difficult climb and the weather was extreme. We reached the summit but the visibility was poor.
G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)
I climbed Carstensz Pyramid with a team of people. It was a difficult climb and the weather was extreme. We reached the summit and I was given a standing ovation.

Style Merchants Style is a company that provides information about the latest fashion trends. Jo Foley, Ned Ingham, Sally Quail, Lily Grimson, and Peter Little are some of the designers who are featured in the company's website.
Ned Ingham designs wedding dresses. He says that people should avoid traditional, stiff dresses and frilly looks in favour of simpler styles. He has been drawing and designing wedding dresses since he was a schoolboy.
Sally Quail is a jeweller. She designed her own engagement ring and set up her own business. Her pieces are sought out by many stars of stage and screen.
Lily Grimson is a handbag designer. She has had two of her creations selected for a major design exhibition. Her bags are handmade in the UK and are full of glamour.
Peter Little is a hairdresser. He has been taking his scissors to some of the world's top heads for over 20 years. He says that most women want real-looking hair and a style they can manage at home.
Penny Pratt is a florist. She has no floristry qualifications and gave up her job as a teacher in order to do 'something different'. Her simple, yet incredibly modern, creations have begun to capture every design prize in the flower business.

The Merrion Hotel is a five-star hotel that has recently opened in Dublin. It is a new hotel that has been built using the latest technology. The hotel has a lot of amenities, including a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, and restaurants.
The Merrion Hotel has a computer system that can deal with return clients in the extra-special way that is appropriate to a five-star hotel. The system cost a lot of money to install, but it will pay itself over time. The hotel also has a system that controls room temperature. Guests can change the temperature themselves within three degrees either side of the normal l8degC.
The Merrion Hotel has a lot of technology in its rooms, including three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that doubles as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility. The hotel has also taken steps to make sure that guests feel comfortable with all of the technology in their rooms.
The Merrion Hotel is likely to be successful because it has a lot of amenities and is well-managed.

Artist Susan Shepherd is known for her flower paintings. She has a large garden that is full of her favourite flowers, mostly tulips and poppies. Some of the plants are unruly and seed themselves all over the garden. There is a harmony of colour, shape and structure in the flower borders that line the paved path. Much of this is due to the previous owners who were keen gardeners. They left plants that appealed to Susan. She also inherited the gardener, Danny.
Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than on the garden as a whole. She picks the plants and takes them up to her studio. She takes one flower out and paints it, which might take a few days. Then, she brings in another flower and builds up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish.
Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer, when the tulips are out. The poppies also come out at the same time. She finds it fascinating to see how the flowers change and grow. She has always been interested in plants. She used to collect wild flowers from all around the countryside. Nowadays, the garden owes much to plants that originated in far-off lands.

The Brackham area had a lot of trees that were brought down in a terrible storm in March. The town itself lost two great lime trees from the former market square. The disappearance of such prominent features had changed the appearance of the town centre. Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, head of the local police force, was not able to notice the change because he was sick. He had been sick with bronchitis and was unable to work. When he finally went to the doctor, he was prescribed antibiotics and was able to go home. The loss of the walnut tree had made a permanent difference to the appearance of the living-room. The room seemed cruelly bright and the worn furnishings were exposed in all their shabbiness. With the tree gone, the room was very different. It was like a new room altogether.

**
Living in the valley, we had been living there for sixteen months. One day, we realized that the hills surrounding our valley could be dangerous. It was the year when the storms came early. The snow started to fall and it was deep. It blocked our lane and made the path slippery. The wind blew fiercely and the trees swayed. But the snow and wind did not really trouble us greatly. It was the river that threatened us most. The river flowed wildly and it was deep. If the dam had not been built, the river would have flooded our village. The dam holds the water back and prevents it from flowing too fast. Now, we can enjoy the huge clouds that hang over the valley and be thrilled by the tremendous power of the river.

**
My first job as a writer was writing articles about films for The Front Page newspaper. Before that, I had done some reviewing of novels and films. I met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who had also written for radio and television. He hired me, but he was not primarily a journalist. He had a different idea. He thought that a team of critics should take care of the art forms that didn't require specialized knowledge. There would be a weekly lunch at which we would make our choices from the artistic material that Tom had decided we should cover. It all felt like a dream at that time. It seemed unlikely that a paper could be introduced into a crowded market. It seemed just as likely that a millionaire wanted to help me personally, and was pretending to employ me.
I chose film as my area of focus. Without Tom's initial push, we would hardly have come up with the present arrangement, by which I write an extended weekly piece, usually on one film. I'm not a judge, and nor would I want to be.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km and then run 1Okm? Because it's fun. A teenager with a taste for endurance wanted: Sports-mad training partner for triathlete, preferably female. The triathlon promises to be one of the most popular Olympic sports. Recently it has drawn huge crowds fascinated (and horrified) by athletes swimming 1500m, cycling 40km, then running 1Okm without stopping.
Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14. She won the junior section - but then she was the only junior taking part. She was full of confidence, so she entered the National Championships, and although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she came nowhere. But she did not give up and is determined that she never will.
Melanie has tried other events. She has had a go at the triathlon 'sprint', for example, where you only have to swim 750m, cycle 20km and run 5km. She wants to enter even tougher events than the triathlon.

The hobby of collecting is a world of passion, envy and enthusiasm. Many people enjoy collecting things, and one in three adults indulges in this hobby. If you enter this world, remember one thing: if you do not fall in love with an object, do not collect it.
People have been collecting things since the beginning of time. Primitive man collected pebbles, and children still collect stones and seashells. You can also collect flowers, pottery, paintings, or even toys.
If you are interested in collecting, there are a few things you need to know. First, you need to find something that you are passionate about. Second, you need to be patient and persistent. Third, you need to be willing to learn from your mistakes.
Collecting is a rewarding hobby that can bring you joy and satisfaction. It is also a great way to learn about history and culture.

My job is to put together temporary exhibitions at the Science Museum. I have to plan and design the exhibition, and promote it. I also have to make sure the public can understand the thinking behind the exhibition.
My job is to teach London taxi drivers. I check the accounts and see what new maps and documents need to be produced. I help students learn the 'runs' or routes necessary to pass the London taxi-driver test.
My job is to work as a marine conservationist. I live by the coast and work from home. I respond to telephone enquiries, produce educational resources and set up training courses.
My job is to publish maps and atlases. I have to make sure that the publishing programme matches market requirements and ensure that we keep stocks of the books that we publish.

No title. We always go to Ireland in June. Every year, the four of us have spent the first fortnight of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a large house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The Malseeds bought the house and have added to it. They have done everything discreetly. We've been playing cards together for ages, Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia and myself. We're all about the same age and live quite close to the town where the Malseeds were before they decided to make the change from England to Ireland.
In the morning, we'd walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee in the hotel there. In the afternoon, we'd drive somewhere. I knew all that because over the years this kind of pattern had developed. Since first we came here, we'd all fallen hopelessly in love with every variation of its remarkable landscape.

A chalet girl's work is never done. Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, is a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. She works for a company that provides chalets for skiers. Sarah's job is to make beds, cook meals, and clean the rooms. She also helps guests with their boots and skis.
Every day, Sarah gets up early and prepares breakfast for the guests. After breakfast, she cleans up and prepares the afternoon tea. She then goes skiing or cleaning the rooms. In the evening, she cooks dinner and prepares the evening tea. Sometimes she will chat with the guests or go out with her friends.
On Sundays, Sarah has a busy day. She starts cleaning early and prepares breakfast for the guests who are leaving. After the guests leave, she cleans the rooms and does the shopping. She then prepares tea for the new guests and helps them get settled in.

Miss Rita Cohen, a young girl, came to Seymour's factory one day. She was small and had a lot of hair. She was doing research into the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. Sometimes, people asked Seymour to give them permission to see his factory. He would sometimes help students by answering their questions or giving them a tour.
Rita was small like the children from Marie's third-year class. Marie's daddy showed her how to make gloves. The gloves were very hot and shiny. Marie called them the 'pancake hands'. Rita was interested in every last detail. She took notes as she asked questions. She was also interested in the tannery. The tannery is a place where they make leather. Her father worked in the tannery. So did she, for six months.
The technology has improved things, but what you'll see isn't that different from what you'd have seen hundreds of years ago. Awful work. It's said to be the oldest industry of which remains have been found anywhere. Six-thousand-year-old relics of tanning found somewhere Turkey, I believe. The first clothing was just skins that were tanned by smoking them.
Rita was a good-natured and intelligent girl. She was eager to learn. He had made her laugh. She had made him laugh. The good-natured intelligence that would just waft out of her and into the house when she came home from school, full of what she'd learned in class.

Chris Arnot asked four people with dream jobs if they're as wonderful as they seem.
A. Raquel Graham is a personal assistant to a pop star. She loves her job and gets on well with her boss, but she can't stand flying.
B. David Brown is a golf caddy. He prefers the golf to his accounting job, but there are drawbacks.
C. Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper. He loves to cook and he was offered a full-time job as a food writer.
D. Dick Prince is a children's writer. He started writing children's stories about 20 years ago and he loves to write letters to his fans.

In the lumberyard by the lake, there was an old brick building. There was a lot of sawdust around the building. One afternoon, Michael was bored and he climbed up the roof of the old building. He invited his friends to jump down, but they were hesitant. One by one, they jumped down and laughed. Michael was still on the roof, watching them. He was thinking about jumping down, but he was afraid. He stayed on the roof for a long time. Finally, he jumped down and lay on the sawdust. He was sad and ashamed. He walked home feeling deeply ashamed.

If you are unhappy with your job, you can turn to a careers adviser. They will ask you to write a brief history of yourself and then conduct a number of tests known as 'psychometrics'. Based on the results of the tests, the adviser will suggest various careers and the retraining needed.
Taking the careers test was like being back in your science exams. It involves picking out mistakes in lists of names and numbers, matching up similar shapes in a set, and answering questions against the clock. After the test, you will have a long chat with the adviser and he will produce a report giving his observations and recommendations.
If you are considering changing your career, you should definitely visit a careers adviser. They can help you to identify your skills and interests and suggest a new career that is more suited to you.

If you walk into W. Lloyd Jerome's dental surgery in the centre of Glasgow, you'll see bright modern paintings on the wall and a comfortable blue couch. Jerome says that many people are afraid to go to the dentist. To make people feel more relaxed, he has tried to create an environment where people are not afraid. He has a lot of relaxation techniques, such as virtual-reality headsets and a pleasant smell in the surgery. He also uses a special instrument that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them, rather than scraping them.
Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to do research into dental techniques. He found out that when you make it easier for the patient, you make it easier for yourself. He sees his patient-centred attitude as the start of a gradual movement towards less formality in the conservative British dentistry profession.

**
Chocolate, which is made in South America, is popular worldwide. People in Britain spend a lot of money on chocolate at Easter and Christmas. The cacao plant was first cultivated by the Aztecs, Toltecs and Mayans over three thousand years ago. The fruit of the cacao tree contains seeds that can be used to make chocolate. The chocolate drink was first made in Aztec times and was used on ceremonial occasions and for welcoming visitors. In the late 17th century, chocolate houses were set up in Europe's capital cities. Until the last century, chocolate was made from solid blocks of chocolate which had to be melted down in hot water. But in 1826, a Dutch inventor named CJ van Houten invented chocolate powder. The age of the chocolate bar as we know it began in 1847. Today, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week.

Peter Cooke is a shell artist who is known for his unique and delicate creations. He has been making beautiful objects out of shells for the past ten years. His work is admired by many people because it is both charming and visually stunning.
Cooke's art is inspired by his love of beautiful shells. He travels to many different countries to find the perfect shells. He only collects dead shells, and he defends himself against people who accuse him of stripping the world's beaches.
Cooke's art is a testament to his creativity and skill. He has created his own unique method of making shells into beautiful objects. His work is a long way from the common shell constructions that can be found in seaside shops.

When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not flying to wonderful locations or appearing on the covers of magazines, she is usually studying for her school exams. One day, the receptionist at the agency told Jane that Kira would be late. Jane was trying to convince herself that all the bad things she had read about models were not true, but the words difficult, vain and unintelligent kept coming into her head. When Kira arrived, she was smiling, relaxed and apologetic. She was not dressed in expensive-looking designer clothes but in a simple black dress and trainers. Kira explained that all models under the age of 16 must take an adult with them whenever they work. She won easily and the Select model agency in London immediately offered her work. Now, Kira has to manage her two separate lives. She has a lot of friends and teachers who are proud of her success, but there are also a few unkind people at her school who are rude about her success. However, Kira is not letting this get her down. She is confident and has a bright future ahead of her.

Father and son, Terence and Chris Madden, travelled from Canada to Africa to find gold. They have a mine on the side of a Welsh mountain that could contain up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging, they are convinced that they are close to a five million dollar vein of gold.
The pair have dedicated their lives to the hunt for gold. They started their search after the father read about pockets of gold worth millions of pounds buried in the 'Dolgellau gold belt'. Since they started their work, they have spent the past ten years getting permission for their work, taking samples of the earth and removing old cars and rubbish. Now they are running short of money and need to convince a backer to put money into the project.
The Welsh gold industry has gone into steep decline since its height in the late 1880s. However, individual gold-diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to drive a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who studies the chemical processes happening in the sea. She teaches and does research into marine geochemistry. When she isn't teaching, she dives down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.
The dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to gather samples, and then three hours to get back up to the surface. If there is a problem, you can hit a panic button and the escape vessel will be released.
Last year, Rachel dived with a Russian crew. They went to a site which was a five-day sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. Here, on the ocean floor, is a huge area of underwater volcanoes.
It's such an adventure diving down to the deepest part of the ocean. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, there is such a sense of wonder.

**
I was tired, smelly, hungry and tanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body and mind couldn't handle any more. I said, "Never again," as I stepped onto home ground. I said exactly the same thing the following year and the next. All I had to do was buy one train ticket and I could spend a whole month going anywhere I wanted in Europe.
The train trip was a valuable personal experience. It was a chance to escape the guided tour and do something different. I took great pride in the fact that I could see the view from the station in many places. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of somewhere that was previously just a name.
Everybody knows what is there, but it is meaningless until you view it yourself. This is what makes other people's holiday photos so boring. While the train trip won't allow you to discover anything new in the world sense, it is a valuable personal experience.

**
There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport overseas and finding that your baggage has been left behind. If your luggage is not with you, you will have to wear the clothes you stand up in for hours or days until the airline finds your luggage. Sometimes, airlines lose luggage, even the best ones. It is impossible to guarantee that your luggage will go on the same flight, particularly when there is a change of aircraft. To make sure your luggage arrives safely, you should choose direct flights whenever possible and check in well before the official time. If a change of plane is unavoidable, try to fly the same airline throughout and allow more connecting time. If your luggage is lost, you must contact the appropriate airline official in the baggage hall and complete a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.

The kingfisher is a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers. It feeds on fish. The bird cuts like a laser through the scene, straight and fast. It has a powerful image that lingers. Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers at an early age. He has a deep feeling for this little bird. He can't identify just what it is that draws him to it. The kingfisher is the stuff of legend. There is some scientific truth in that story. For despite the many different blues that appear in their coats, kingfishers have no blue pigment at all in their feathers. Rather, the structure of their upper feathers scatters light and strongly reflects blue. The kingfisher is a popular bird to photograph. It is easy to watch from a hideout. You can see a kingfisher in a woodland stream. If you are interested in photography, you might like to photograph kingfishers.

Becoming a conductor is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.
A. Anne Manson was asked to help on an opera the next season. She was nervous at first, but she was able to take the first orchestral rehearsal for Abbado. She has also assisted Abbado on several more projects.
B. Andrew Constantine won a major competition in 1991. He is finding it difficult to lose the 'competition' label. But orchestras are now inviting him back.
C. Wasfi Kani loves the long practice period which is part of any opera production. She started conducting seriously in her late twenties.
D. Roger Vignoles started out as a resident musician with an opera house. He was asked to direct Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival.
E. Wayne Marshall was noticed by a conductor in 1986. He soon found himself conducting a musical in London.

If you're thinking of taking children to a theme park in Britain, there are many to choose from. We asked five families to test the best.
There are rides for all ages at most theme parks. Younger children can enjoy the Crocodile Ride, the Giant Wheel, and the dodgems ride. Older children can enjoy scarier rides, such as Splash Out and the ferris wheel.
The park is clean, well-organized, and has a lot of staff to help you. You can also put your feet up and relax.
If you have a full day to enjoy the park, you can experience all that it has to offer. There are rides, games, and shows. You can also enjoy the scenery and the atmosphere.

Running a business in the countryside is a rewarding experience for many women. There are a few challenges, but there are also many advantages.
A few women talk about their experiences setting up a business in the countryside. Some of the women run businesses that are related to their hobbies, such as design, art, and publishing. Other women run businesses that are related to their skills, such as curtain-making and cake-baking.
One of the biggest challenges of running a business in the countryside is the lack of financial support. It can be difficult to get loans or find investors. However, there are also a number of advantages to running a business in the countryside, such as the ability to work from home and the ability to be your own boss.
Overall, running a business in the countryside can be a rewarding and fulfilling experience. It is important to be aware of the challenges, but it is also important to focus on the many advantages.

Meet the Watkins family. They are musicians. The sons are composers and prize-winning musicians, while Dad makes the instruments.
John and Hetty Watkins had a son, Paul, who was a talented cellist. They needed to get him a cello, but it was very expensive. So John decided to make one himself. He took evening classes and learned how to make instruments. After a few tries, he made a cello for Paul.
Paul was very happy with his cello. He used it to win a competition and was appointed principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra. Now he has a new cello that is even better than his father's.
Huw, Paul's brother, is also a musician. He is a pianist and composer. He is beginning to make his own mark as a musician.

**
The National Trust is an organisation that protects the British countryside. Gill Page visited the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talked to one of the wardens employed by the Trust.
A National Trust Warden needs common sense and good handling skills. Gareth Roberts was born and bred on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he married. He won the job because of his local knowledge and farming experience.
Gareth's job includes conservation, public entry to the Trust's land, tree planting and maintenance, and meeting the Trust's tenant farmers. He also has to make sure jobs get finished and deal with reports and bills.
Most of Gareth's time is spent on reports, signing bills and other paperwork. But he also enjoys talking to the public and seeing projects completed.

Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is captain of the England team. She has a typical day for the weeks leading up to the World Championships. She teaches at a local school and has a training session in the local supermarket car park.
The World Championships are big and there will be a lot of pressure on the team. The first game is against Barbados. The team is ranked fourth in the world, but the Championships will be tough.
Kendra is proud of her team and she is excited about the Championships. She has a strong mental attitude and she leads by example. She also thinks it is important to have a good training program and to be able to concentrate on your movements and your feet.
As captain, Kendra has a lot of responsibility. She has to make sure that her team is ready for the game and that they are playing their best. She also has to be able to motivate and encourage her team.

If a child has a natural talent for music, it can be difficult to know how to develop and encourage their gift. Many parents may not recognize or respond to their child's need until frustration explodes into difficult or uncooperative behaviour. Most schools are not able to deal with children who are especially able in music. If a child has a lot of musical ability, they may benefit from the education offered by a specialist music school.
There are five music schools in Britain that offer a sympathetic environment for gifted children aged between seven and eighteen. At these schools, children spend a lot of time on musical activities, such as individual lessons, orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting and theory. They also spend several hours a day practising in properly equipped private rooms.
There are some disadvantages to attending a specialist music school. One disadvantage is the cost. The fees are high, but each school will make every effort to help parents find the necessary fees. Another disadvantage is that not all parents want to send their children to boarding school. Finally, it can be stressful to be a musically gifted child. But all specialist schools do keep a close watch on the progress of individual pupils, and offer help and advice if needed.

Artist Susan Shepherd is known for her flower paintings. She has a large garden that is full of her favourite flowers, mostly tulips and poppies. Some of the plants are unruly and seed themselves all over the garden. There is a harmony of colour, shape and structure in the flower borders that line the paved path. Much of this is due to the previous owners who were keen gardeners. They left plants that appealed to Susan. She also inherited the gardener, Danny.
Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than on the garden as a whole. She picks the plants and takes them up to her studio. She takes one flower out and paints it, which might take a few days. Then, she brings in another flower and builds up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish.
Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer, when the tulips are out. The poppies also come out at the same time. She finds it fascinating to see how the flowers change and grow. She has always been interested in plants. She used to collect wild flowers from all around the countryside. Nowadays, the garden owes much to plants that originated in far-off lands.

A chalet girl's work is never done. Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, is a chalet girl in Val d'lsere, France. She works for a company that provides chalets for skiers.
Sarah's day begins early. She gets up at 7 a.m. and walks to the chalet. She has breakfast and prepares breakfast for the guests. After breakfast, she cleans up and makes the afternoon tea. She then goes skiing. She skis as much as possible, sometimes until 4.30 p.m.
When she returns to the chalet, Sarah prepares dinner and takes a shower. She does not sleep. Dinner is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. After dinner, Sarah clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests, other times they are content to be left alone.
On Sundays, Sarah has a busy day. She starts cleaning early and prepares tea for the new guests. Sometimes she takes guests to the ski shop and gets a lift back to the chalet. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a chat with friends.

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent the day at the office of the magazine Marie Claire. She had a busy day, going to a photo studio, press previews, and a fashion shoot. The zoo is a peaceful place, and Mandie enjoyed giving animals a cuddle.
Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent the day at London Zoo. She was given a polo shirt to wear and stroked one of the elephants. She had a great day and felt satisfied.
Karen Hodson, a nurse, went on location with the television gardening programme Ground Force. She was excited to meet the team and enjoyed being in the fresh air. She felt weak compared to the rest of the team but still had a great time.
Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. He made beds and handed out tablets. He felt his job was a waste of time compared with nursing but still felt satisfaction.
Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent the day with the airline Ryanair as a member of the cabin crew. She felt different when she put on the uniform and felt self-conscious. She also felt surprised by the number of schoolchildren on the flight.
Sonia McDermott, an air hostess, spent the day as a personal trainer in a gym. She was dreading doing this swap but was amazed at how much attention you give to one person. She felt satisfied that she had inspired others to join the gym.

Five celebrities tell Andrew Morgan their favourite memories of railway journeys. Each celebrity has a unique story to share. Andrea Thompson loves the south of France and the amazing seascapes that can be seen from the train. Raj Patel enjoyed his family train journey to the Kruger National Park, even though he was not able to go. Betty Cooper remembers the dress she wore on her honeymoon and the lovely journey through France and Egypt. Martin Brown had a memorable experience travelling across the desert in Africa. Arisu Mezuki shared her passion for steam trains and the film she made featuring a railway in Yorkshire.
The celebrities all agree that travelling by train is a special experience. They appreciate the beauty of the landscapes and the opportunity to interact with people from all over the world. They also enjoy the sense of adventure and wonder that comes with travelling by train.

If you want to get your story published, there are a few things you need to do. First, you need to research your markets and find out about publishers. You also need to practice your writing skills. To become a successful writer, you need to develop a knowledge of the markets you are aiming at. You can do this by reading everything relevant you can lay your hands on.
Once you have done your research, you need to start writing. Write as much as you can and keep practicing. Each story you write will be better than the last. If you have only written one story or one article, it is not likely to be published. But don't give up. Keep writing and eventually you will get published.

On the last day of a bad year, I was waiting for the train in the Baltimore railway station. There were a lot of people waiting. The station was not clean and polished like it usually is. There were elderly couples with their luggage and college kids with their bags. A man was walking around talking to different strangers. He looked well-off. He went up to a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. He also came over to me and asked me if I was travelling to Philadelphia. I said yes, but he didn't ask me to go with him. I understood why he didn't. He seemed unreliable. He went on to talk to another woman and asked her to help him. She agreed to help him. The train was announced and people started moving to the gate. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, which would have been the logical choice. I let my eyes wander toward the two of them. It looked like he was trying to hide something.

John Moore, a restaurant owner, writes about his relationship with his son Gary, a famous TV chef. Everyone has a chance in life, and John believes that his son Gary was given his chance with cooking. When John heard about the opportunity, he rushed to look at the place. It was in a really bad state, but it was perfect for what he had in mind.
John's wife dedicated herself to looking after the children and did all his accounts, while he ran the business. They lived over the restaurant and always put a lot of emphasis on having meals together. Their children, Gary and Joe, are both very confident. From a very early age, Gary would come down and talk to the regular customers. It's given both of them a great start in life.
Gary was quite a lively child when he was really small. He had discipline and was always up even before his dad in the morning. If you run a family business, it's for the family, and it was nice to see Gary helping out. By the age of 15, Gary was as good as any of the men working there. He would produce over a hundred meals, and from then I knew he'd go into catering because he had that flair.
John's advice to Gary would be: if you start chasing two hares, you end up catching neither, so chase the hare you know you're going to catch. Gary went to catering college at the age of 17 and was successful. No one can believe how successful Gary's TV cookery series has become. John is extremely proud of him.

Finding a good flat in Dublin was like finding gold in the gold rush. If you knew someone who knew someone who was leaving a place, that often worked. But if you had just arrived in Dublin, there was no chance of any personal contact. You had to stay in a hostel and search.
Jo felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she got on the train to go and work there. She didn't ask herself why she was going there in the first place. She was heading off on her own.
There was an advertisement for a flat in Ringsend that said, 'Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom.' It was very near the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true.
The flat was upstairs and there was a cheerful-looking girl coming down the stairs. 'Desperate place,' she said to Jo. 'They're both awful. Common as dirt.'
Jo went on climbing and met a punk named Pauline. She had seen some of them on O'Connell Street, but hadn't met one close up to talk to.

**
Dolphins are popular animals that people love to see. They are intelligent and sensitive to human emotions. They also allow us to dream of freedom. However, dolphins are facing a number of threats, including pollution, overfishing, and human disturbance.
There are many different kinds of dolphins. Some dolphins live far out in the open sea, while others live near to coasts. The bottlenose dolphin is one of the most common kinds of dolphin. Bottlenoses are social creatures that live in groups. They are often seen in river mouths and coastal waters.
One of the biggest threats to dolphins is pollution. Pollutants can build up in the bodies of dolphins and can cause a number of health problems. Another threat to dolphins is overfishing. If fish are caught in fishermen's nets, they may not be able to find food or they may be injured. Human disturbance is also a major threat to dolphins. Noise pollution from ships and oil wells can disturb dolphins and make it difficult for them to communicate.
Dolphins are an important part of the ecosystem. They help to regulate the food chain and they are a source of joy for people all over the world. It is important to protect dolphins so that they can continue to live and thrive.

Getting fit is important for your mind, body and spirit. It's a great way to stay healthy and feel better. There are many reasons why you should exercise. It can improve your muscle tone, strength, posture and flexibility. It can also help you to prevent injuries, relieve stress and improve your mood. If you're not sure how to start, you should talk to your doctor. You can do many different types of exercise, such as aerobics, jogging, working out with weights or stretching. To get the most out of your exercise, you should warm up before you start, stretch after you exercise, and cool down afterwards.

In their natural habitat, film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman are often away from their home comforts for months on end. They are searching for the perfect shot. Two of the hardest creatures to track down in East Africa are Amanda and Owen. Their present habitat, the Ngorongoro Crater, has been affected by a lot of rain. They had to invest in an expensive piece of equipment to help them when their vehicles get stuck in the mud. Their partnership has created some of TV's finest wildlife films. They have been travelling the world to film exotic wildlife since the birth of television.
One day, I spoke to Newman about their partnership. He said that they sometimes argue, but they usually get over it quickly. They don't regard themselves as leaders. They see the animals in a similar way. They spend a lot of time setting up camp and making tea. Their diet consists of pre-packed meals and tea. It can be a rough existence, but the appeal of being alone in such remote areas is that they can get close enough to the animals to become part of their lives.

Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is captain of the England team. She has a typical day for the weeks leading up to the World Championships. She teaches at a local school and has a training session in the local supermarket car park.
Kendra is very focused on her training. She says, "My whole life now is all about making sure I'm at my absolute best for the Championships." She is on a strict timetable to gain maximum fitness for the Championships.
The World Championships will be tough. There will be a lot of pressure on the England team. But Kendra is confident that they can win. She says, "You have to push yourself to play each day, there's no rest between games as in a series. And you can still win an international series if you lose the first game. But the Championships are different because there's only one chance and you have to be ready to make the most of it."
As captain, Kendra has a strong mental attitude and leads by example. She says, "From the very beginning, my netball career has always been carefully planned." So she took the decision some time ago that this competition would be the end of it as far as playing is concerned.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who studies the chemical processes happening in the sea. She teaches and does research into marine geochemistry. When she isn't teaching, she dives down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.
The dive can last for 16 hours. If there is a problem, you can hit a panic button and the escape vessel will be released. It's like letting go of a ping-pong ball in the bath.
When Rachel isn't at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre. She loves teaching and she uses her salary to fund her research into underwater volcanoes.
The only time Rachel has been frightened is when she first went down with the Americans. There was an explosion and she thought, "I'm going to die." But she was still alive and she felt relief.

First impressions are often lasting ones. People form impressions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They observe how we dress, our eye contact, our body movement and how fast or slowly we talk, our volume and tone of voice as well as our actual words.
Mary Pearce was studying to be a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree and was confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. However, she didn't get the job. The Head Teacher said that if someone doesn't take the time to present their best image at an interview, what kind of teacher is she going to be?
It is important to have a professional image and to communicate clearly. If you want to do well in an interview, you should dress professionally, make good eye contact, and speak clearly and concisely. You should also be prepared to answer questions and show that you are interested in the company.

Matt Froggatt was an insurance agent in London. He decided to leave his job and start a sheep farm. He was made redundant and had enough money to set up the farm. He also started supplying meat through mail order.
Ron Able was a manager in advertising. He decided to become an artist. He talked to a career counsellor and went to the north of England to start his new business.
Katherine Goodison was a lawyer. She decided to set up her own business making hats. She left her job and started her own business. She feels happier and less stressed now.
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance. He decided to become a masseur. He spent a year travelling and getting qualifications. He has no regrets.

Four young sports stars talk about their lives. They are all dedicated to their sports. They have to train hard and make sacrifices to be successful.
Darius is a runner. He has competed for his country and won a medal. He doesn't get much media attention, but he is still proud of his accomplishment.
Gabriel is a surfer. He has won the National Championships and is now a celebrity. He has to give up late-night parties and have a lie-in to train.
Dieter is a yacht racer. He has a lot of fun with his friends and enjoys the camaraderie. He doesn't like being recognized as a celebrity.
Tomas is a tennis player. He loves playing in front of the crowd, but he also has to deal with the downside of being famous. He has to travel a lot and split up with his girlfriend.

Young shoppers often go to the supermarket with their parents. Sometimes, they want everything they see. If it's not the latest cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually, all three. Parents sometimes have a hard time deciding which demands should be agreed to and which should be refused. They also admit they are inconsistent and hypocritical in their responses to their children's purchasing requests. Supermarkets could do a lot more to ease parent-child conflict by removing sweets from checkout areas or even by providing supervised play areas.

The Merrion Hotel is a five-star hotel that has recently opened in Dublin. It is a new hotel that has been built using the latest technology. The hotel has a lot of amenities, including a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, and restaurants.
The Merrion Hotel has a computer system that can deal with return clients in the extra-special way that is appropriate to a five-star hotel. The system cost a lot of money to install, but it will pay itself over time. The hotel also has a system that controls room temperature. Guests can change the temperature themselves within three degrees either side of the normal l8degC.
The Merrion Hotel has a lot of technology in its rooms, including three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that doubles as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility. The hotel has also taken steps to make sure that guests feel comfortable with all of the technology in their rooms.
The Merrion Hotel is likely to be successful because it has a lot of amenities and is well-managed.

Where I get my energy, Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the full to tell us how they do it. They said that the best way to get energy is to do things that you enjoy and that make you feel good.
A. Jeanette Kupfermann is a journalist and author. She says that she gets energy from doing things that are challenging and rhythmic. Dance is a very expressive and energising activity.
B. Linda Kelsey is an editor. She says that she gets energy from being at work and exercising. She also needs a good night's sleep.
C. Annie Nightingale is a disc jockey. She says that she gets energy from being positive and enjoying life.
D. Floella Benjamin is an author and children's TV presenter. She says that she gets energy from working with kids and communicating with others.
E. Deborah Moggach is an author and playwright. She says that she gets energy from making a garden and writing.
F. Katherine Monblot is a therapist. She says that you should have an interest in and respect for what you do in life.

Ice skating has a long history. People have been skating for thousands of years. In the past, people used skates made from animal bones. Now, people use skates made from metal. Skating is a popular sport that can be enjoyed by people of all ages. To skate, you need to be relaxed and have good balance. You also need to know how to fall safely. If you are new to skating, you should start by learning the basic figures. Once you have mastered the basic figures, you can move on to more advanced moves. Skating is a great way to improve your balance, coordination, and relaxation. It also improves heart and lung activity and generally strengthens the body.

There is a story about some young stars who won medals in different sports.
A young girl named Annika won a gold medal for gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to become a physiotherapist and compete at the next Olympics. It takes a lot of time and energy to be a champion. But Annika is very determined and she never gives up.
Another young girl named Sarah made her first show-jumping appearance at ten. She has won the British National Championship. To be successful in show-jumping, you have to jump all over England and save money. Sarah is well-organized and she is always happy on a horse.
A young girl named Jane is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. She loves to play chess and she is very good at it. It's a friendly game and it's fun. Jane is not scared of getting big-headed or embarrassed.
These young stars are all very successful and they are an inspiration to everyone.

Chris Greener was tall when he was young. He is the tallest man in Britain. Every year, more and more people are born who are tall. This does not mean that humanity is producing a new super race. We are returning to what we were like as cavemen. Our ancestors ate a wide variety of foods, including fruits, berries, and herbs. About 9,000 years ago, agriculture was invented. This has had a disastrous effect on human health and physique. Today, most people eat a diet that is based on three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize. This poor diet has had a negative impact on human health. However, there is a positive trend. The average man in the US, Holland, and Japan is now taller than he was in the past. This is due to improved nutrition. However, there are also some problems. For example, leg-room in planes and trains has shrunk. The question is: where will it all end? We cannot grow forever. We must have some programmed upper limit.

Studio audiences are a common feature of television life. They are made up of people from all classes, professions and income groups. People often go to studio audiences to appear on television, take a look behind the scenes, or simply have fun.
When you sit in a studio audience, you are squashed among strangers and someone flashes cards with APPLAUD or LAUGH on them. You clap or laugh accordingly. This may reflect the reality of some television, but not all by any means.
Going to a studio may be a terrible way to watch television, but that's not what's important. For most of the audience, it was simply fun and a free night of entertainment.

**
Bruce likes landscapes that have a human element. He finds it important to have people in the landscape. When he travels abroad, he likes to visit lovely villages with old temples. He also likes to explore the countryside. He finds the landscape familiar yet different from his home in Scotland. He used to describe his adventures in his private diary. That was his first attempt at travel writing.
Sophia loves a miniature railway that goes from Hythe to Dungeness. She always travels first class. The scenery is not spectacular. But there is one point on the journey that she always looks forward to - when the train goes through back gardens. She sees herself in the eyes of the people who live in the houses.
Matthew likes the Hartland Peninsula. The beaches are hard to reach and scattered with rocks. He prefers to reflect on the majesty of the sea. The coast, which faces the Atlantic, is notorious for shipwrecks. There are coast walks which you can combine with trips inland up beautiful damp valleys.
Annette's favourite place in England is the Trough of Bowland. It's a landscape of wide-open moorland which is perfect for hiking. There are not many residents and not many visitors either. It's an unknown corner, empty and remote, and she likes the feeling of space.
James purchased Glenthorne, his favourite house in Britain. It was a question of obtaining pure peace and reconnecting with his English roots. He grew up in what is now known as Sri Lanka, but at the age of twelve went to school in Devon, in the west of England. He used to cycle around the moors and village backstreets. He finds Glenthorne to be a magical, secluded, romantic house.

We love animals. One day, my daughter found a pine snake. We decided to keep it overnight. I was late getting home and when I arrived, there was a crisis. Domino the cat and Bianca the mouse were running around the bedroom. I tried to help, but I tripped over something and fell on the floor. The snake escaped and I was scared. I crouched like a rabbit and the snake was hissing and striking at me. I managed to capture Domino and pull the mouse from its jaws. I looked the snake over for weak points, but it didn't have any. I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer and the snake relaxed. I eventually released the snake and it went away.

**
In our fast-paced world, letter writing is at risk of disappearing. But to me, there is something special about receiving a letter that cannot be matched by any other form of communication. It's the excitement of its arrival, the pleasure of seeing who it is from and the enjoyment of the contents.
I have been writing letters for as long as I can remember. I started writing to my mom when I was young. My mom always insisted that I write my own thank-you letters. When I left home to train as a doctor, I would write once a week. My parents and I wrote letters to each other regularly. I also wrote letters to my boyfriends. It was a way to stay in touch.
I love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. I also appreciate notes, but I like to have a lot of news. It's better to have a year's supply of news than a few notes. I have penfriends in different countries. I have a penfriend in France, Australia, and Vancouver. I also have a penfriend in Texas.
I am pleased that my children are carrying on the tradition of letter writing. Like my mom before me, I insist that they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter and son have penfriends of their own. I strongly urge readers not to allow letter writing to become another 'lost art'.

Tens of thousands of ancient pictures carved into the rocks at Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged. The drawings include pictures of cows with horns, cultivated fields and various gods and goddesses. But as the popularity of the site increases, the pictures are being ruined by thoughtless graffiti.
The drawings are being damaged rapidly and will not survive for future generations. People are stamping on the drawings, wearing away the rock and definition of the artwork as they do so. Some visitors even chop off parts to take home as souvenirs.
Experts are divided over the best way to preserve the drawings. Some believe that the only way to save the site is to turn the whole mountain into a 'no-go' area. Others believe that the best solution is to let people look at the site but charge a fee.
The site was classified as a historic monument years ago by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do as much as possible to save what is there. If we do not take steps, the drawings will be lost for future generations.

Young shoppers often go to the supermarket with their parents. Sometimes, they want everything they see. If it's not the latest cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually, all three. Parents sometimes have a hard time deciding which demands should be agreed to and which should be refused. They also admit they are inconsistent and hypocritical in their responses to their children's purchasing requests. Supermarkets could do a lot more to ease parent-child conflict by removing sweets from checkout areas or even by providing supervised play areas.

**
Once upon a time, climbers went to the mountains. Now, you can climb anywhere, indoors or out. The crowd holds its breath. High above them on the climbing wall, there is a climber named Francois Lombard. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. The National Indoor Arena is famous for staging the TV show Gladiators, but it also has a climbing wall. The climbing wall is made of bricks with special edges that climbers can hold on to. Many sports centres started building walls specifically for climbing. These walls have many holds that climbers can use to grip and climb.

**
If you want to become an actor, it's a risky career. There are a lot of actors, but not enough jobs. If you choose to become an actor, people may tell you that you're crazy. But it's a personal choice and only you can take responsibility for yourself. There are no easy ways to become an actor. You need talent and luck. There is a demand for new faces and new talent. Acting is all about making contact with the audience. If you ask actors how they have done well, they will not know. They will know certain things about themselves and aspects of their own technique and the techniques of others. But they will take nothing for granted. Disappointment is the greatest enemy of the actor. You need to be prepared for rejection. If you don't care enough, no-one will care for you.

Chris Greener was tall when he was young. He is the tallest man in Britain. Every year, more and more people are born who are tall. This does not mean that humanity is producing a new super race. We are returning to what we were like as cavemen. Our ancestors ate a wide variety of foods, including fruits, berries, and herbs. About 9,000 years ago, agriculture was invented. This has had a disastrous effect on human health and physique. Today, most people eat a diet that is based on three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize. This poor diet has had a negative impact on human health. However, there is a positive trend. The average man in the US, Holland, and Japan is now taller than he was in the past. This is due to improved nutrition. However, there are also some problems. For example, leg-room in planes and trains has shrunk. The question is: where will it all end? We cannot grow forever. We must have some programmed upper limit.

Matt Froggatt was an insurance agent in London. He decided to leave his job and start a sheep farm. He was made redundant and had enough money to set up the farm. He also started supplying meat through mail order.
Ron Able was a manager in advertising. He decided to become an artist. He talked to a career counsellor and went to the north of England to start his new business.
Katherine Goodison was a lawyer. She decided to set up her own business making hats. She left her job and started her own business. She feels happier and less stressed now.
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance. He decided to become a masseur. He spent a year travelling and getting qualifications. He has no regrets.

Two brothers, Dave and Norm Lagasse, are playing a game called pichenotte. It's a game that their grandfather brought to the USA from Canada. The game is popular in their home state of New Mexico. They have made their own boards and are selling them to people.
Pichenotte is a game of skill. Each competitor gets 12 pieces or 'pucks'. The pucks are flicked across a board using the middle or index finger of one hand. If you flick a puck into a small hole, you get 20 points. The game usually lasts just two minutes.
The Lagasses have made a lot of money from selling their boards. They have sold more than 450 boards. They are made of birchwood and mahogany, and they weigh 12kg. You can buy one of their boards for $595.

Welcome to the Model Village. When you first enter the village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago, this was just wasteland. The village was built by one man, Colin Sims, and his wife. They worked hard to change the wasteland into the beautiful village you see today. Many tons of soil and clay were moved to create the village. Hundreds of trees and shrubs were also planted. The models in the village are made from a variety of materials, including stone, concrete, and wood. They are very detailed and accurate. The village is popular and is known for its high standard of workmanship and maintenance. You can also enjoy the village by pressing the buttons on some of the working models. We hope you enjoy your visit to the Model Village.

Every week, British newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy. These pictures often include celebrities and other people who are in the public eye. Sometimes, these pictures are very private and can be very hurtful to the people who are pictured. However, very few people call on the services of the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which is an organization that was set up to deal with issues of this kind. The PCC has not launched an investigation into any of the recent stories about celebrities' privacy. This is a scandal. The PCC should take the initiative on this and other shameful attacks. It would be a good idea to have the PCC take on this role of 'police officer'. However, there are some problems with this idea. It would be difficult to decide whether or not to launch an inquiry. And it would also be embarrassing for the people who are pictured.

A lot of advice is available for college leavers heading for their first job. If you are taking a real step on the career ladder and choosing a job to fit in with your ambitions, you need to ask yourself what you want to achieve in the long term. You should choose your second job very carefully and aim to stay in it for two to three years. It should be a job that extends you, develops you and gives you increasing responsibility. If you have the travel bug, now is the time to pack up and go. You can do temporary work for a while when you return and get the second job then. Future potential employers will be relieved to see that you have got it out of your system and are not likely to go off again.

Confident people have learned that confidence is a skill that can be learned. There are many things that you can do to become more confident.
Some people become confident by working hard and being popular in their work. Others become confident by tackling things that scare them, such as taking a driving test or speaking in public. Still others become confident by believing in themselves and not letting others discourage them.
If you want to become more confident, there are a few things you can do. First, you need to believe in yourself and not let others discourage you. Second, you need to set manageable targets and work towards them. Third, you need to take action and start doing things that scare you. Fourth, you need to surround yourself with positive people. Finally, you need to remember that everyone experiences challenges and setbacks, but that you can overcome them with hard work and determination.

Paul Forster went to a kite-flying festival in Malaysia. He spent a nervous night in the forest. He was given a kite that was traditional and had plenty of other kites. They sat down in the shade of the trees and looked at the festival. The kites flew into the air like rockets. There was a competition with more than 500 men and boys. Each had entered four different designs. The festival ran for five days. Paul decided to stay in a hut in the forest. Night was totally black and there was a lot of different sounds. In the morning there was a tremendous view over the mountains. It rained in the afternoon. Paul slid downhill and wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the enormous drops. He was glad that his car was still there. No one is a stranger for long in Kelantan.

What kind of shopper are you? Everyone goes shopping, but there are different types of shoppers. Do you know which kind you are? Abby Edwards asked around and found out that there are different types of shoppers. Some people are addicted to shopping, like Melanie and her boyfriend. They love spending money and they often drag each other around the shops. Other people are reluctant shoppers, like Brenda. They don't spend much time shopping and they often feel guilty when they spend money. Still other people only shop for essentials, like Juliet. They hate shopping and only go when they really have to. And there are people who like a good look round every now and then, like Anita. They know what they want and they get in and out as quickly as they can.
